description: Application under Section 73A to vary condition 2 (Approved Plans) of planning permission 19/01820/FUL (erection of 1 x 6 bedroom two storey house with rooms in roof and basement and single storey detached garage) to alter the roof form of the garage and insert two dormers in its front roof slope to provide habitable accommodation within the roof space.
decision_conditions: Within three months of the date of this permission, a sample of the facing materials to be utilised in the development hereby permitted shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The development shall then be built in accordance with these approved samples.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of Part 1 of Schedule 2 of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (or any Order revoking or re-enacting this Order) no extensions (including porches or dormer windows) to the dwelling houses or buildings shall be erected within the curtilage.Reason: To safeguard the privacy and amenity of adjoining occupiers, maintain adequate amenity space and safeguard the cohesive appearance of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (or any Order revoking or re-enacting this Order) no windows or other openings (other than those hereby approved) shall be formed in the south-western elevation at first floor level or above, of the building hereby approved without the prior written consent of the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No part of the development hereby approved shall be occupied until evidence has been submitted to the council confirming that the development has achieved not less than the CO2 reductions (ENE1), internal water usage (WAT1) standards equivalent to Code for Sustainable Homes level 4. Evidence requirements are detailed in the "Schedule of evidence Required for Post Construction Stage from Ene1 & Wat1 of the Code for Sustainable Homes Technical Guide. Evidence to demonstrate a 19% reduction compared to 2013 part L regulations and internal water usage rates of 105l/p/ day must be submitted to and approved by the Local Planning Authority, unless otherwise agreed in writing.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation in accordance with Policies 5.2 (Minimising Carbon Dioxide Emissions) and 5.3 (Sustainable Design & Construction) of the London Plan (July 2011) and Policy DM1 (Sustainable Design and Construction Standards) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in strict accordance with the landscaping scheme approved under 19/00489/COND. The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following completion of the development and the tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority. Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced in the first available planting season, and the area shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose only.Reason: In the interests of visual amenity and also that the Local Planning Authority shall be satisfied as to the details of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development shall be implemented in accordance with the details and tree protection methodology set out within the Arboricultural Impact Assessment & Method Statement dated 23 August 2019. The protection scheme shall be implemented prior to commencement of any work associated with the proposed orangery and maintained to the reasonable satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority until the completion of the development.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and in the interests of visual amenities and so that the Local Planning Authority shall be satisfied as to the details of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the details shown on the submitted landscape plan, a revised landscape proposal shall be submitted to and approved in writing within three months from the date of this permission, to show the following modifications:(i) the hedge HED1 made up of Hornbeam across the Northern boundary of the site replacing the previously substantial hedge to be planted across its entire length.(ii) the continuation of this hedge to the Western Boundary planted to match as an instant hedge (fully grown from a specialist provider) at a minimum height of 2m.The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following completion of the development and the tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority. Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced in the first available planting season, and the area shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose only.Reason: In the interests of visual amenity and also that the Local Planning Authority shall be satisfied as to the details of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in strict accordance with the refuse storage and recycling facilities approved under 19/00489/COND. These facilities shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted and shall thereafter be retained for use at all times.Reason: To ensure the provision of refuse facilities to the satisfaction of the Council in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

All works on site shall take place in strict accordance with the details approved under 19/00489/COND regarding:(a) Provision for loading/unloading materials.(b) Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles.(c) Temporary site access.(d) Signing system for works traffic.(e) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works.(f) Location of all ancillary site buildings.(g) Measures to protect any tree, shrubbery and other landscape features to be retained on the site during the course of development.(h) Means of enclosure of the site.(i) Wheel washing equipment.(j) The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitors(k) The erection and maintenance of security hoarding.Reason: In order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Within three months of the date of this permission, details of the implementation, adoption, maintenance and management of a sustainable drainage system have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The system shall be implemented and thereafter managed and maintained in accordance with the approved details. Those details shall include a timetable for its implementation, and a management and maintenance plan for the lifetime of the development which shall include the arrangements for adoption by any public body or statutory undertaker, or any other arrangements to secure the effective operation of the sustainable drainage system throughout its lifetime.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and to prevent the increased risk of flooding in accordance with Policy CS1 (Climate  Change Mitigation) of the Local Development Framework Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in strict accordance with the details of the fences, walls or other means of enclosure proposed to be erected along the boundaries of the site which were approved under 19/00489/COND.Reason: In order to ensure the privacy of adjoining occupiers and visual amenity of the area is retained in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in strict accordance with the details of secure and covered cycle parking facilities which were approved under 19/00489/COND. These facilities shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted and shall thereafter be retained for use at all times.Reason: To ensure the provision of refuse facilities to the satisfaction of the Council in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Before any occupation of the development hereby approved, the windows in the South West elevation and situated on the first floor of the building hereby permitted, shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable. Any part below that level shall be fitted with, and retained in, obscure glazing of a patterned type only which shall thereafter be retained as such.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The garage and car parking accommodation shown upon the approved drawings shall be provided with a hard bound dust free surface, adequately drained before the development to which it relates is occupied and thereafter it shall be kept free from obstruction at all times for use by the occupier of the development and shall not thereafter be used for any purposes other than the parking of vehicles for the occupiers of the development and visitors to it.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking accommodation and to avoid the congestion of surrounding roads by parked vehicles in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.
Condition 3 (Material Samples) - Officers have reviewed the samples provided and are satisfied this can now be approved.

Condition 4 (Construction Logistics Plan) - RBK Neighbourhood Traffic Engineer has reviewed the information provided and is satisfied this can now be approvedThe applicant is reminded of the following;Section 59 of the Highways Act permits the Highway Authority to charge developers for damage caused by excessive weight and movements of vehicles to and from a site. The Highway Authority will pass on the cost of any excess repairs compared to normal maintenance costs to the applicant/organisation responsible for the damageThe developer is reminded that it is an offence to allow materials to be carried from the site and deposited on or damage the highway from uncleaned wheels or badly loaded vehicles. The Highway Authority will seek, wherever possible, to recover any expenses incurred in clearing, cleaning or repairing highway surfaces and prosecutes persistent offenders. (Highways Act 1980Sections 131, 148, 149).

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.Representations12 surrounding owner/occupiers were notified of the proposals.  One letter has been received regarding the following summarised concerns:o	Loss of daylight/sunlighto	Inappropriate scale/designOfficer response: The raised concerns will be addressed in the assessment.  The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: It is acknowledged that the proposed extension would not be strictly in accordance with Policy Guidance 39 of the Council's Residential Design SPD as the proposed extension to the dormer would not be set back from the side as required. Officers note massing of the dormer (the total enlargement), however it is considered to be acceptable in this case as it would appear as a proportionate and subordinate addition in relation to the host dwelling and would not change significantly the existing situation in terms of visual impact.The proposed rear dormer extension would not be visible from the street. The proposed installation of 2 rooflights to the front is considered acceptable and in-keeping with the host dwelling and the surrounding area.  Given the above, it is considered that there would not be significant impact on the existing street scene as a result of the proposal. As such, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Due to the nature of the proposal, its scale and siting it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan, Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Condition 5 (Refuse Storage and Recycling) - Elevations for the refuse storage were requested via email on 26/01/2021. No elevations have been provided. As such, Officers are unable to support this conditions apporval due to lack of infomation provided.
Condition 9 (Landscaping Scheme) - RBK Tree & Lanscape officer has reviewed the information submitted and is satified this can now be approved.
Condition 10 (Secure Cycle Parking) - RBK Neighbourhood Traffic Engineer has reviewed the information provided and is satisfied this can now be approved

Condition 11 (Refuse Storage Facilities) - Elevations for the refuse storage were requested via email on 26/01/2021. No elevations have been provided. As such, Officers are unable to support this conditions apporval due to lack of infomation provided.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above are agreed and that Condition 3 (Material Samples), Condition 4 (Construction Logistics Plan), Condition 5 (Refuse Storage and Recycling), Condition 9 (Landscaping Scheme), Condition 10 (Secure Cycle Parking) and Condition 11 (Refuse Storage Facilities) of planning permission 19/00323/FUL are hereby fully approved.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.Representations:12 surrounding owner/occupiers were notified of the proposals.  One letter has been received regarding the following summarised concerns:- Loss of daylight/sunlight- Inappropriate scale/designOfficer response: The raised concerns will be addressed in the assessment.  The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The total enlargement of the roof comprising the proposed extension to the existing dormer and the existing dormer, given its scale, would result in a dominant and bulky addition to the host dwelling. The proposed development would be a disproportionate addition that would be excessive in terms of its bulk, scale and mass, in conflict with Policy Guidance 39 of the Council's Residential Design SPD.The proposed installation of 2 rooflights to the front is considered acceptable and in-keeping with the host dwelling and the surrounding area.  Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Due to the nature of the proposal, its scale and siting it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. In conclusion, the proposed extension of the rear dormer, together with the existing dormer would by virtue of its size, siting and design create an incongruous addition to the host property that would be visually intrusive and detract from the character and appearance of the host property and the surrounding area. The proposal would not accord with policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012.

This application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal conflicts with relevant planning policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises The London PlanRBK Core Strategy 2012This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of and and buildings.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered unacceptable in terms of scale/form/bulk/height/massing/spacing/design in respect of the two storey side extension. It is considered that there would be an unacceptable adverse impact on the character and appearance of the area as a result of this element of the proposals. It is considered that it would erode the spaciousness between the host property and that of 91 Portland Avenue that exists and would fail to take the opportunity to redress the imbalance of the pair of semi-detached properties created by the hip to gable extension at 95 Portland Avenue. As such the proposal misses the oppurtunity to improve the character and appearance of the pair of semi-detached properties and would as a result further exacerbate the imbalance in the properties. It is considered that it would create an incongruous feature that would be dominant and overbearing and visually intrusive in the streetscene and detract from the character and appearance of the surrounding area. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not have an unacceptable adverse impact upon the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance/loss of light/loss of privacy.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.One objection was received on the grounds that the proposed first floor extension would lead to loss of privacy and that the ground floor extension would result in more intensive use of the rear section of the garden, which would in turn result in noise and disturbance. The objection also states that overall, the proposal would be out of character with the existing property and surrounding development. These matters will be considered below.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed ground floor extension would project 1.5m beyond the existing rear building line of the property and infill to provide a square layout at ground floor. It would be topped by a parapet roof with a maximum height of approximately 3.2m, which is within the range of heights recommended by the Council's Residential Design SPD. The proposed first floor extension would infill some of the space along the boundary with 8 Cleaveland Road, projecting 1.5m beyond the existing rear wall in this location.Given the overall size of the existing property, officers consider the proposed extensions to be moderate in scale. Accordingly, it is concluded that they would appear as subordinate and proportionate additions to the host property. Although it is recognised that the flat roof form of the proposed first floor extension would be at odds with that of the host dwelling, the scale of this element of the proposal and its location would mean that its impact on the character and appearance of the area would be very limited. Meanwhile, the ground floor extension would have the appearance of a typical contemporary extension, the likes of which are seen on properties of varying ages and styles throughout the borough.Having regard to the above, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: While it is recognised that the proposed first floor extension would result in a window being inserted closer to the rear boundary than is presently the case, it would still be approximately 17m from the rear boundary and approximately 25m from the nearest opposite window. Given these distances are both well in excess of the Council's guidance on separation distances, officers are satisfied that the proposal would not result in any materially harmful loss of privacy to neighbouring occupiers. In terms of overbearing appearance and loss of light, officers recognise that the proposal would involve a first floor extension right up against the boundary with 8 Cleaveland Road. However, the depth of the extension is such that officers do not consider it would appear overbearing and it would also pass the 45 degree test in relation to the nearest adjacent window. At ground floor level, the increase in the length of wall along the boundary with 8 Cleaveland Road (relative to the existing rear projection) would be very limited (1.5m) and officers conclude that it would not appear overbearing or materially reduce the availability of natural light versus the existing relationship.In terms of noise and disturbance, officers consider it unlikely that the proposal would result in a material intensification in the use of the rear section of the garden. However, such an intensification would, in any event, involve nothing more than the typical use of the garden of a single family dwelling.Having regard to the above, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light, loss of privacy, noise or other disturbance.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan, Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The current application is made pursuant to Section 73 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (asamended), which concerns applications to develop land by removing or varying conditions previouslyattached. In this case, the application is to vary condition 1 (the approved plans) of planning permission19/02785/FUL.

The site comprises a detached dwelling.Seventeen neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.RBK Tree and Landscape Officer - is satisfied witht the information provided and raises no objection to the permission being issued on the condition that they implement the permission in strict adherence to the submitted documents and statements.The current application is made pursuant to Section 73 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended), which concerns applications to develop land by removing or varying conditions previously attached. In this case, the application is to vary condition 4 (Aboricultural Report) of planning permission 20/01110/HOU.While this is, in effect, a fresh application for the entire development, the principle of the development was nonetheless established by the granting of 20/01110/HOU and Section 73(2) of the Act explicitly states that "on such an application, the local planning authority shall consider only the question of the conditions subject to which permission should be granted". It would therefore, be unnecessary and unreasonable to revisit every issue which was relevant to the determination of the original application.Having regard to the nature of the variations sought under the current application, officers consider that the assessments made under the original application on the following issues remain unaltered:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) states that The Council will expect new development to ensure that trees that are important to the character of the area or covered by Tree Preservation Orders are not adversely affected. Policy Guidance 7 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) state that generally there will be a presumption against the loss of trees - regardless of whether they are protected by virtue of a Tree Preservation Order or with respect to their location within a designated Conservation Area. Officer Comment: The proposed changes to the previously approved Arboricultural Report are considered to be acceptable and will not result in harm or loss of trees within a conservation area or under a tree protection order.In conclusion, the proposal is considered to be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which indicate that permission should be refused. Accordingly, it is recommended that planning permission be granted.
Invalid site location and block plan showing incorrect address provided.

The submitted application refers to approved plans FLU.1101.01(D), 02, 03, 04(G) and 05(F) and the Proposed Variation relates to FLU.1101 01(D), 02,03, 04(P) and 05(O)However it appears we do not have the full set of the 2 sets of 5 plans. Please may we ask that you send these plans again and this application will be validated as of the agreed date of 06/08/2021

Please submit a copy of an Ordnance Survey based site location plan scaled 1:1250 with the application site outlined in red and adjoining land owned by applicant in blue, showing at least two road frontages and a North point.Please note that the full extent of the site should be shown and not just in part. The red line should relate to the building to where the proposed works are being carried out and the blue line to any of the adjoining property which is owned by the applicant
Drawing 1002-A   has incorrect title "Proposed floor plans" when it shows existing elevations.Please correct and resubmit asap to avoid any further delays
Please provide a description of works in writing
Please provide information regarding the amount by which you seek to reduce each tree by in metres or by percentage.

Due to Covid-19 and the effect this has had upon working procedures, the Tree Officer will be unable to carry out site visits in the majority of cases. For the foreseeable future, if making an application or notification for works to a protected tree please ensure that you or your agent provide clear photos of each tree, labelled T.1, T.2 and so on, in order that they can be identified according to the list of works you wish to carry out and the matching numbered plan showing the location of each tree. This will enable the Council to provide you with a timely decision in line with the standard processing times.Could you please title all of the photos that were submitted via the Planning Portal and re submit.

Please confirm the following:- that the proposed roof lights would not protrude more than 0.15 metres beyond the plane of the slope of the original roof when measured from the perpendicular with the external surface of the original roof- that any window located on a roof slope forming a side elevation of the dwellinghouse must be—(a) obscure-glazed; and(b) non-opening unless the parts of the window which can be opened are more than 1.7 metres above the floor of the room in which the window is installed.
